container.heading: Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Board.
para.text: "Board" means the Baltimore City Board of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing.

para.heading: Business.
para.text: "Business" means any person engaged in an enterprise for profit that operates in Baltimore City.

para.heading: Complainant.
para.text: "Complainant" means the person who initiated a complaint to the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing under this subtitle.

para.heading: Department.
para.text: "Department" means the Baltimore City Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing.

para.heading: Director.
para.text: "Director" means the Director of the Baltimore City Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing or the Director's designee.

para.heading: Respondent.
para.text: "Respondent" means a business that is the subject of a complaint under this subtitle.

para.heading: Unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practices.
para.text: "Unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practices" has the meaning stated in Title 13 of the State Commercial Law Article.

section.heading: Department established.
section.text: There is a Baltimore City Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing.

section.heading: Purpose.
section.text: The purpose of the Department is:

para.text: to centralize the administration of City business licenses, permits, and practices specified in subsection § 42-9 {"Business practices under oversight of the Department – Listing"} of this subtitle;
to ensure compliance with City licensing requirements;
to ensure City businesses are properly licensed and operating in accordance with City law;
to investigate claims of unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practices; and
to enforce business licensing and consumer protection provisions of the City Code.

section.heading: Powers.
section.text: The Department may:

para.text: administer, oversee, and enforce City business licenses, permits, and practices, including business processes and related licenses created by the subtitles specified in § 42-9 {"Business practices under oversight of the Department – Listing"} of this subtitle;
receive complaints and take action to investigate complaints of:
businesses operating without a license;
businesses operating with improper licensing;
businesses violating the terms of a business license; and
unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practices against consumers under City Code Article 2, Subtitle 4 {"Unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practices"};
set licensing fees, with the approval of the Board of Estimates;
bring enforcement actions against a business for violating City law, including initiating a hearing before the Board of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing;
issue summonses and subpoenas during an investigation under this subtitle;
issue environmental citations, as described under subtitle 40 of this article;
issue civil citations, as described under subtitle 41 of this article;
report to any appropriate government agency with jurisdiction any information concerning violation of any consumer protection law; and
advise the Mayor and City Council on issues relevant to City business licensing and consumer protection.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Director is responsible for the administration and oversight of the Department.

para.heading: Appointment.
para.text: The Director is appointed by the Mayor in accordance with Article IV, § 6 of the City Charter.

para.heading: Salary.
para.text: The Director shall receive such salary as may be provided for in the Ordinance of Estimates.

para.heading: Staff.
para.text: The Department may employ staff in accordance with the Ordinance of Estimates.

para.heading: Budget.
para.text: The Department may expend funds authorized in the Ordinance of Estimates or any supplemental appropriations.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director must adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

section.heading: Annual report.
section.text: On or before June 30 of each year, the Department must submit an annual report for the previous calendar year to the Mayor and City Council that details:

para.text: the activities of the Department; and
complaints received by the Department, including the following information:
number of complaints filed and investigated by the Department;
number of investigations initiated by the Department;
nature of complaints filed with the Department; and
the disposition or resolution of each complaint or investigation; and
recommendations for additional legislation and policy to regulate business licensing and protect consumers.

section.heading: Business practices under oversight of the Department – Listing.

container.heading: Board of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing

section.heading: Established.
section.text: There is a Board of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Board comprises the following 5 members, appointed by the Mayor in accordance with Article IV, § 6 {"Appointments of municipal officers."} of the Baltimore City Charter:
1 member nominated in consultation with the President of the City Council;
1 member nominated in consultation with the City Comptroller; and
3 members named by the Mayor, at least 2 of whom must be members of the Maryland Bar; and
1 member of the City Council

para.heading: Qualifications.
para.text: A Board member must:
be an individual of known personal integrity;
possess a recognized knowledge in business licensing or consumer protection; and
be a resident of the City of Baltimore.

para.heading: Staff.
para.text: The Director shall designate Department staff to assist the Board in carrying out its functions.

para.heading: Terms.
para.text: A Board member shall serve a term of 4 years, concurrent with the terms of the Mayor and the City Council and, at the end of a term, a Board member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualified.

para.heading: Chair.
para.text: The members of the Board shall annually elect a chair from among the members of the Board.

para.heading: Vacancies.
para.text: If there is a vacancy in the membership of the Board, the new member shall be appointed in the same manner as the previous member.

para.heading: Compensation.
para.text: The members of the Board shall receive no compensation for their services on the Board, but shall be reimbursed for the reasonable and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties.
The Board shall meet at least monthly.
A majority of the members of the Board constitutes a quorum for the transaction of business.

para.heading: Attendance at meetings.
para.text: Any appointed member of the Board who fails to attend 4 consecutive meetings without good cause, as determined by the Mayor, shall be deemed to have resigned.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Board shall adjudicate all hearings of the Department, unless otherwise provided by law.

para.heading: Other duties.
para.text: In coordination and consultation with the Department, the Board shall:
review and propose improvements to existing City rules, regulations, and laws with respect to business licensing and consumer protection;
research and recommend new programs and training that could be delivered to consumers and businesses; and
evaluate current programs and proposed legislation to determine their impact on consumers and businesses.

para.heading: Informational hearings and studies.
para.text: As appropriate, the Board may hold informational hearings and undertake surveys and studies to:
evaluate existing City policies and procedures in regard to business licensing and consumer protection; and
make recommendations for the improvement of existing policies and procedures to the Director.

para.heading: Annual report.
para.text: The Board shall submit an annual report on its activities to the Department to be included in the Department's annual report to the Mayor and City Council, as described in § 42-8 {"Annual report"} of this subtitle.

text.strong: Upon Receipt or Issuance of Complaint

para.text: Any person may file a written complaint with the Department alleging that a business is:
operating without a license;
operating with improper licensure;
violating the terms of a business license; or
engaging in unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practices against consumers.
A complaint filed under this subsection must be in the form required by the Director.

para.heading: On Director's motion.
para.text: The Director may issue a written complaint alleging that a business is committing or has committed 1 or more of the acts described under § 42-28(a) {"Investigation procedures: Initiation of investigation"}.
Upon receipt or issuance of a complaint, the Department must, via regular mail, send a copy of the complaint to the business named in the complaint.
The business named in the complaint shall be the respondent.

para.heading: Confidentiality.
para.text: For a complaint filed under § 42-26(a) {"Commencement of action: On complaint of other"} of this subtitle, the Director must redact from the copy sent to the respondent:
the complainant's name; and
to the fullest extent possible, any other information that might identify the complainant.

para.heading: Initiation of investigation.
para.text: The Department shall investigate a complaint alleging that a business is:
operating without a license;
operating with improper licensure; or
violating the terms of a business license; or
engaging in unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practices.

para.heading: Complaint not within jurisdiction of Department.
Dismissal and referral.
para.text: If a complaint is not within the jurisdiction of the Department under subsection (a) of this section, the Department shall dismiss the complaint and, if appropriate, refer the complaint to another entity with jurisdiction over the matter.

para.heading: Notification.
para.text: If a complaint is dismissed under this subsection, the Department shall promptly notify the complainant and respondent.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Upon receipt or issuance of a complaint, the Department shall promptly investigate the complaint.

para.heading: Subpoenas.
para.text: In the course of an investigation, the Department may issue a subpoena to require any person to:
produce information, documents, reports, records, accounts, or any other evidence related to the allegations in the complaint; and
appear under oath to give testimony related to the allegations in the complaint.

para.heading: Oaths.
para.text: The Director may administer oaths as permitted under this section.

para.heading: Report of findings.
para.text: The Department shall prepare a written report of findings as soon as practicable after the conclusion of the investigation.

section.heading: Director's action upon completed report of findings.

para.heading: Actions.
para.text: If the Director determines that the report of findings contains information tending to substantiate an allegation in the complaint, the Director may, as appropriate for the nature of the offense and subject to other applicable law, take 1 or more of the following actions:
refer the complaint for a hearing before the Board;
issue a civil citation;
issue an environmental citation;
provide the respondent with the opportunity to remedy the behavior at issue in the complaint; and
pursue any other legal or equitable relief or enforcement available under the law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: If the Director determines that the report of findings does not contain information that tends to substantiate an allegation in the complaint, the Director shall dismiss the complaint and, if appropriate, refer the complaint to another entity with jurisdiction over the matter.

para.heading: Notification.
para.text: If the Department dismisses a complaint under this subsection, the Director shall promptly notify the complainant and respondent of the dismissal.

para.heading: Action on licenses.
para.text: Before revoking or suspending a license, the Department must provide notice and opportunity for a hearing before the Board, unless otherwise provided by law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In lieu of any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, a person operating a business that is required to be licensed by one of the subtitles listed under § 42-9 of this subtitle may be issued a civil citation for:
operating a business without a license;
operating a business with an improper license; and
operating a business in violation of the terms of a license.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce the provisions of a business license created in the subtitles listed under § 42-9 of this subtitle does not preclude the City from pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: If the Director refers a complaint for a hearing before the Board under § 42-29 {"Director's action upon completed report of findings"} of this subtitle, the Board must provide the respondent with notice and an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.

para.heading: Representation by counsel.
para.text: In any hearing conducted by the Board, the respondent is entitled to be represented by counsel.

para.heading: Subpoenas.
para.text: The Board may issue a subpoena to require any person to:
produce information, documents, reports, records, accounts, or any other evidence; and
appear under oath to testify.

para.heading: Oaths.
para.text: The Chair may administer oaths as permitted under this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: If, upon consideration of the entire record produced at the hearing, the Board finds by a preponderance of the evidence that the respondent has violated the City Code, the Board may, as appropriate for the nature of the offense and subject to other applicable law, take 1 or more of the following actions:
issue an order directing the respondent to cease and desist from the violation;
issue a reprimand;
revoke or suspend the respondent's license;
report to any appropriate government agency with jurisdiction any information concerning a violation of any law;
order the respondent to restore money or property to the person who made the complaint;
order the respondent to pay any costs of investigation or related activities of the Department;
impose and order the respondent to pay any relevant civil penalty authorized by law; and
take any other action that would:
assist the person who made the complaint in obtaining relief; or
prevent future violations of law.

para.heading: Considerations.
para.text: In ordering any remedy, the Board shall consider:
the severity of the violation;
the severity of any harm to consumers;
the motives of the respondent;
any previous violations by the same business or business owner;
whether the remedy will deter future misconduct; and
whether a stop order or restitution would sufficiently protect consumers or the person who made the complaint.

para.heading: Subpoenas.
para.text: If any person does not comply with any subpoena issued under this subtitle, the Director may enforce the subpoena by seeking injunctive or other appropriate relief in a court of competent jurisdiction.

para.heading: Civil penalties.
para.text: The Director may bring an action in any court of competent jurisdiction to recover any civil penalty imposed by the Director or the Board.

para.heading: Board orders.
para.text: The Director may bring an action in any court of competent jurisdiction to enforce any order, decision, or other enforcement action of the Board.

para.heading: Injunctive relief.
para.text: The Director may seek injunctive or other appropriate relief in a court of competent jurisdiction to enforce any provision of law under the Department's jurisdiction.

section.heading: Assistance of City Solicitor and other departments.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Office of the City Solicitor shall reasonably assist the Department and Board in carrying out the Department's and Board's respective duties under this subtitle, including in any judicial enforcement action.

para.heading: Authority to bring action.
para.text: Nothing in this subtitle shall limit the authority of the Office of the City Solicitor to bring an enforcement action under City Code Article 2, Subtitle 4 {"Unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practices"}.

para.heading: Assistance of other City departments.
para.text: The Department and Board may request the assistance of other City departments as necessary to carry out the Department and Board's respective duties under this subtitle.

section.heading: Judicial review.
section.text: A respondent or other person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board or Director under this subtitle may seek judicial review of that decision by petition to the Circuit Court for Baltimore City in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: To the extent permitted by the Maryland Public Information Act, after a complaint is filed:
the proceedings, meetings, and activities of the Department, the Board, and the Department's staff relating to the complaint are confidential; and
neither the Department, the Board, nor the Department's staff may disclose any information relating to the complaint, including the identity of the complainant or the respondent.

para.heading: Identity of respondent.
para.text: The Department may release any information other than the complainant's identity if the respondent has agreed in writing to the release.

para.heading: Identity of complainant.
para.text: The Department may disclose the complainant's identity to the respondent if the complainant has agreed in writing to the release.

para.heading: Duration.
para.text: To the extent permitted by the Maryland Public Information Act, the confidentiality protections imposed by this section terminate when the Director or Board determines that the respondent or another person has violated any provision of the City Code under the Department's jurisdiction.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In accordance with the terms of this subtitle, the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing shall appoint as many auctioneers in the City of Baltimore as the Director may deem proper, not to exceed 50.

para.heading: Application.
para.text: Applications for appointment shall be under oath on a form approved by the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing and shall contain the applicant's qualifications for appointment.

section.heading: Designation of associates.
section.text: Within 30 days of his appointment, and upon any change thereafter, every auctioneer shall deposit with the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing the names of all officers, associates, partners, or employees designated by him to conduct auction sales.

para.heading: Amount and tenor.
para.text: A surety bond, in the amount of $25,000, with a surety approved by the City Comptroller, conditioned on the auctioneer's performance in accordance with the provisions and intent of this subtitle, shall be posted prior to the issuance of any license and shall remain in effect during its term.

para.heading: Filing.
para.text: Said bond shall be filed in duplicate with the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing, and the duplicate shall be forwarded to the City Comptroller for his signatory approval and returned to the Director.
In the event the surety leaves the State or becomes insolvent, the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing shall demand a substitute surety.

If the auctioneer fails to provide other security within 15 days after such demand, the license issued thereupon shall become null and void and the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing shall give notice thereof in 2 or more daily newspapers.

Upon the receipt of an approved surety bond and of a $1,600-license fee paid to the Director of Finance, the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing shall issue a license to a duly appointed auctioneer for the term of 1 year.
At the request of the applicant, the license may be dated back to the expiration date of his prior license, but such action shall not affect prosecutions commenced prior to such request.
The failure of the auctioneer to pay the license fee and post bond within 30 days of his appointment shall render such appointment null and void.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: On timely notice and hearing by the Board of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing, and receipt of the Board's recommendation, the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing may suspend or revoke the license of any auctioneer for any violation of this subtitle for which a civil liability or criminal penalty may be imposed.

section.heading: Auction sales of jewelry — merchant's stock.

para.text: It must be held on successive days, Sundays and legal holidays excepted, and shall not continue for more than 30 days in all.

A period of at least 365 days must have elapsed after the conclusion of any auction sale, conducted either before or after the enactment of this subtitle, before another auction sale shall be commenced by the same merchant.

para.heading: Hours.
para.text: It must be held only between the hours of 8 a.m. and 6 p.m., and at no time within the hours beginning at 6 p.m. and ending at 8 a.m.

para.heading: Location.
para.text: Such auction sale must be held:
either:

at a place at which the merchant so selling his or its goods at auction conducted the jewelry business in Baltimore, for the period of at least 90 days immediately prior to the commencement of said auction sale; or
at the regular and usual auction rooms of some duly licensed auctioneer; and
at no other place or places.

Not more than 15 nor less than 10 days before commencing any sale, the merchant must file with the Police Commissioner of Baltimore City and the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing a statement setting forth:
the name and address of the merchant so intending to conduct said sale;
the place or places at which for the year next preceding said date of sale such merchant has conducted his or its business;
the date or dates on which the merchant secured a trader's license for said business;
the locations of and purpose of the proposed sale;
the probable duration thereof;
the name and address of the auctioneer who will conduct said sale;
an inventory showing in detail the quality, quantity, kind, or grade of the goods, wares, and other articles proposed to be sold; and
that no items or articles belonging to any other person or corporation than said merchant are included in said inventory.
Said statement must be subscribed by such merchant or an officer thereof (if a corporation), and verified by the oath before a notary public of the person so subscribing.

At least 2 days before the commencement of such sale the auctioneer named in the foregoing statement shall file with said Police Commissioner and the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing an affidavit subscribed and sworn to by him:
referring to said statement; and
setting forth
that he has been employed to conduct said sale at the time and place named therein; and
that he will keep a true record of any and all lots or items sold at said sale, and the prices obtained therefor.

Within 10 days after the conclusion of said sale, said auctioneer shall file with said Police Commissioner and the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing a report subscribed by said auctioneer and sworn to by him before a notary public:
showing all the articles so sold at said auction sale, and the price at which sold; and
certifying that no articles were sold which were not included in the foregoing statement.

para.heading: Sale limited as in statement; signs.

para.text: No items or articles not set forth in the statement and inventory filed by such merchant in accordance with the provisions of subsection (d) preceding shall be sold or offered for sale at said auction sale.
All articles so sold must be sold at the property of and under the name of the merchant so conducting said sale.

During the conduct of said sale, a sign or signs must be maintained at the place of said sale plainly visible to persons attending the same, showing the name and address of the merchant whose goods are so being sold at auction.

para.heading: Other business prohibited during sale.
para.text: Except in the case of auction sales conducted at the rooms of some duly licensed auctioneer, as set forth in subsection (c) preceding, during the time when and while such auction sale is being conducted, no business other than the jewelry business which had been conducted for the period of 90 days immediately prior to the commencement of said auction sale, shall be conducted or engaged in at and in the place so designated in the statement filed with the Police Commissioner of Baltimore City and the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing.

para.heading: Subdivided premises as "place".
para.text: For the purpose of this section, should any person or persons or corporation erect, construct, or install, either temporarily or permanently, any mere partition, shade, blind, or any other similar device which may divide or separate that part of said building so used for the purpose of sale, repair, or dealing in gold, silver, plated ware, precious stones, watches, clocks, or jewelry, and so holding a trader's license for such business, from the remaining part of the same building, then said entire premises so divided or separated shall be construed and defined as "place".

para.heading: Licensor.
para.text: "Licensor" shall mean the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing of Baltimore City.

para.heading: Renewal fee.
para.text: The fee for this renewal of license shall be $50 payable to the Director of Finance.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing in consultation with the Police Commissioner may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

section.heading: Permit or photo ID required.
section.text: No individual may remove scrap from any premises in the City, transport scrap through any street or alley in the City, or sell or offer to sell any scrap in the City unless the individual has, on his or her person:

para.text: a permit to do so from the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing; or
a valid driver's license or other valid photographic identification issued by the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration.
An application for a permit under this subtitle must:
be on the form that the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing; and
contain the information that the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing requires.
The application for an initial license must be made in person, at the places the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing designates.
Applications for a renewal license need not be made in person.

para.heading: Issuance.
para.text: The Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing must issue a permit to the applicant if:
the applicant is 18 years old or older; and
in the Director's discretion and judgment, the public health, safety, or security will not suffer by the permit's issuance.

section.heading: Permits — Refusal or revocation.
section.text: The Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing may refuse to issue a permit and may revoke any permit already issued if:

para.text: within the preceding 5 years, the scrap collector or scavenger was convicted of larceny, burglary, or receiving stolen goods; or
the Director finds that:
the scrap collector or scavenger has violated any provision of this subtitle; and
the public health, safety, or security would suffer by the issuance or continuance of the permit.

para.heading: Hours — Special permissions.
para.text: On application by a scrap collector or scavenger, the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing may authorize additional or alternative hours if:
he scrap collector or scavenger has an established place of business in the City or an adjacent county; and
the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing finds that the restrictions imposed by this section would be a health or safety hazard or create an unjust hardship.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

section.heading: License required.
section.text: No person may do business as a scrap metal dealer unless that person:

para.text: has first obtained all State licenses for the business; and
has then obtained from the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing a City license under this Subtitle 8 {"Scrap Metal Dealers"}.

section.heading: Applications.
section.text: The application for a license shall:

para.text: be made in the form and contain the information that the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing requires; and
contain a notarized statement that attests, under penalties of perjury, to the truth of all information provided.

para.heading: Amount.
para.text: The application fee and annual license fee for each place of business are as set by the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing, with the approval of the Board of Estimates.

section.heading: Denial, suspension, etc., of license.
section.text: The Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing may deny, suspend, revoke, or refuse to renew a license if, after giving the applicant or licensee notice and an opportunity to be heard, the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing finds that the applicant or licensee:

para.text: has made a material misstatement or omission in any application for an initial or renewal license;
has failed to maintain in good standing any State license required for the business;
has violated a provision of:
this Subtitle 8 {"Scrap Metal Dealers"};
State Business Regulation Article Title 17, Subtitle 10 {"Junk Dealers and Scrap Metal Processors"}, as found by a court of competent jurisdiction; or
a rule or regulation adopted under either of these laws; or
has engaged in a pattern and practice of receiving stolen goods.

para.heading: Judicial review.
para.text: A person aggrieved by a decision of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing under § 8-11 {"Denial, suspension, etc., of license"} of this subtitle may seek judicial review of that decision by petition to the Circuit Court for Baltimore City in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: Appellate review.
para.text: A party to the judicial review may appeal the court's final judgment to the Court of Special Appeals in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: No retail dealer shall engage in the business of selling motor fuel at retail without first procuring from the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing a license for each station, store, garage or other establishment at which his said business is to be conducted.

para.heading: Issuance; term.
para.text: Licenses issued under this section:
shall be issued upon written application to the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing;
shall be issued only to persons, firms, or corporations who own the business to be licensed and who are the owners or lessees of the premises on which the business is to be conducted;
shall be effective from the date of their issuance until January 1 of the ensuing year; and
shall be renewed annually.

para.heading: Fee.
para.text: A license fee of $150 shall be paid for the issuance of every such license and every renewal thereof.

para.heading: Display of license.
para.text: Each licensee shall conspicuously display his license at the station, store, garage, or other establishment to which it pertains.

para.heading: Requirements supplemental to any other law.
para.text: The requirements of this section with respect to licenses are hereby declared to be in addition to, and not in substitution for, license requirements contained in any other statute or ordinance.

Except as provided under subsections (b) and (c) of this section, whoever, himself or by his agent or servant, violates any provision of this subtitle shall be punished by a fine of not less than $10 nor more than $100.

Upon the 2nd conviction of any licensee or any such violation, whether by himself or by his agent or servant, the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing may suspend the right of such licensee to engage in the business of selling motor fuel at retail for a period not exceeding 3 months.

Upon a 3rd or subsequent conviction of any license of any such violation, whether by himself or by his agent or servant, the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing may suspend such right for a period not exceeding 1 year.

para.heading: Maximum number.
para.text: The 45 pawnbroker licenses issued as of May 18, 1994, shall be the maximum number of pawnbroker licenses that may be issued in the City of Baltimore.

para.heading: Issuance.
para.text: After May 18, 1994, the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing of Baltimore is hereby authorized to transfer licenses under the corporate seal, to such person, firm, or corporation as shall produce to him satisfactory evidence of his, her, their, or its good character, to exercise or carry on the house or business of pawnbrokers, which licenses shall designate the house in which such person, firm, or corporation shall respectively be licensed to carry on the said trade or business.
Each person, firm, or corporation receiving the said license shall pay therefor the sum of $2,000 annually.
The annual license fee shall be collectible pursuant to Article 15, Subtitles 46 and 47 of the City Code.

para.heading: Renewals.
para.text: The license granted as aforesaid may be renewed on application to the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing each and every year on payment of the same sum.

para.heading: Compliance with zoning and urban renewal laws.
para.text: All transfers shall comply with the provisions of Zoning Code of the Baltimore City Code and with any applicable urban renewal ordinance.

No person shall use, exercise or carry on the trade or business of pawnbroker in this City, without having such license as aforesaid, nor in any other house than the one designated in said license, unless in case of removal.
The Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing shall endorse on said license the house to which the party shall have removed.
Each pawnbroker shall submit to the Police Commissioner and the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensinga daily report of all articles taken on pledge.
The pawnbroker shall forward the daily report to the Police Department and the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing, as provided in § 11-7 of this subtitle.

para.heading: How.
para.text: A pawnbroker shall submit each daily report to the Police Department and the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing in the following formats:
by electronic transmittal, in the format and manner required by the Police Commissioner; and
if the electronic transmission is not submitted with an electronic signature acceptable to the Police Commissioner, in writing, on the forms supplied by the Police Commissioner.

para.heading: Dealer to allow inspection.
para.text: A pawnbroker shall allow an authorized law enforcement officer or a special enforcement officer, as defined in City Code Article 19 § 71-1 {"Appointment; Duties"}, on request to enter the place of business or storage premises of the dealer during business hours to inspect a record of transactions and/or items as part of an investigation of stolen property.

section.heading: Suspension or revocation of license.
section.text: The license of any pawnbroker who has violated 2 or more provisions of this subtitle within a 12-month period may be suspended or revoked by the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing if there appears to him sufficient cause for so doing.

para.heading: Director of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing to issue.
para.text: The license shall be issued by the Director of the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing.

para.heading: "Cooperative" defined.
para.text: In this section, "cooperative" means:
a facility that is owned and operated for the benefit of, and that provides space, clerical services, or other support services at a single location for, 2 or more dealers; or
any group of contiguous stores or outlets that are owned and operated as a single establishment.

para.heading: Master license authorized.
para.text: Subject to the rules and regulations of the Police Commissioner and the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing, including provision for identifying member dealers as they change from time to time, the owner or operator of a cooperative may obtain 1 master license to cover all member dealers in the cooperative.

This master license fulfills the license requirements for all dealers who have been identified to the Police Commissioner and the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensingas members of the cooperative.
Member dealers remain individually responsible, however, for all reporting, identification, record keeping, retention, and other requirements of this subtitle.
The owner or operator who obtains the master license is not personally liable for any act or omission of a member dealer to which the owner or operator was not a party.

Each dealer shall submit to the Police Commissioner and the Director of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing a daily report of each transaction in which a person transfers items to the dealer on that day.
The dealer shall forward the daily report to the Police Department and Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing, as provided in § 12-8 of this subtitle.

para.heading: How.
para.text: A dealer shall submit each daily report to the Police Department and the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensingin the following formats:
by electronic transmittal, in the format and manner required by the Police Commissioner; and
if the electronic transmission is not submitted with an electronic signature acceptable to the Police Commissioner, in writing, on the forms supplied by the Police Commissioner.

section.heading: Retention of records.
section.text: For at least 3 years after the date of a transfer, the dealer shall hold all records of the transaction:

para.text: at the dealer's place of business; or

if otherwise specifically required by the dealer's property insurer, at some other suitable location designated by the dealer and from which the dealer can produce the records as and when needed by the Police Department and the Department of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing.

para.heading: Dealer to allow inspection.
para.text: A dealer shall allow a law enforcement officer or special enforcement officer, as defined in City Code Article 19, § 71-1 {"Appointment; duties"}, acting in the line of duty, to:
enter the dealer's place of business or storage premises during business hours; and
inspect any record of transactions subject to this subtitle and any items on the premises.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Police Commissioner, in consultation with the Director of Consumer Protection and Business Licensing may adopt rules and regulations to implement this subtitle and shall make these rules and regulations available to dealers and the general public.

section.text: The following officials and employees must file the financial disclosure statements required by this subtitle:
